thread.title: Suspect shot multiple times after pulling gun on police in North Sacramento - Sacramento Bee
thread.title_full: Suspect shot multiple times after pulling gun on police in North Sacramento - Sacramento Bee

title: Suspect shot multiple times after pulling gun on police in North Sacramento - Sacramento Bee
text:
February 10, 2017 2:18 PM Suspect shot multiple times after pulling gun on police in North Sacramento Sacto 911 
Covering crime, police and courts in the Sacramento region Two dozen Sacramento police officers remain at an active crime scene in North Sacramento that already resulted in one suspect being shot by officers. Anita Chabria achabria@sacbee.com The Sacramento Police Department is investigating an officer-involved shooting in the 2900 block of Del Paso Boulevard. Sacramento Bee file photo Law enforcement officers prepare to enter the area where hostages were believed to be held on Friday in the Del Paso Heights area. Jose Luis Villegas jvillegas@sacbee.com 1 of 3 i 
By Anita Chabria 
A 28-year-old parolee was shot multiple times during a gun battle with law enforcement Friday afternoon in North Sacramento, according to police. 
Around 2 p.m. in the 2900 block of Del Paso Boulevard, a Sacramento police officer and a Sacramento County Sheriff’s deputy approached the suspect after monitoring him as a dangerous parolee at large, said Sacramento police spokesman Sgt. Bryce Heinlein. The man drew a handgun and then fired at a K-9 unit. 
Three Sacramento police officers and the Sheriff’s deputy returned fire, striking the man multiple times. The suspect was shot and transported to the hospital, where he is in stable condition, Heinlein said. 
Police are planning to send a robot into a house at the crime scene to ensure that no active threats remain, Heinlein said. 
A witness, Margo Santana, said she is in an adjacent house and can hear children from the house under surveillance. Heinlein said he could not confirm that children or any suspect remained in the house. 
The nearby area has been locked down, and police advise motorists to avoid the area. 
Hagginwood Elementary School on Palo Verde Street placed themselves on lockdown as a precaution, said Zenobia Gerald, Twin Rivers Unified School District spokeswoman. She said school officials are releasing students on a class by class basis. 
Hagginwood Elementary parents have been notified about the lockdown and will be called when they can pick up students. 
Return to sacbee.com for updates. 
Diana Lambert and Cathy Locke contributed to this report. Anita Chabria: 916-321-1049 , @chabriaa Related content
